ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
1. Working under a multi-disciplinary approach to history 
2. Elements of cultural/social history about self-identification and evolution of societies 
3. Close reading of medieval sources and deciphering information from them
4. Discussion of historiography 
5. General knowledge about subject matter (there is a lot of unexpected stuff here, from random stuff like buckets with burials to the origins of Anglo-Saxon identity)
6. The course also devoted much time to the writing process, and how to incorporate historical evidence into writing
I learned to write about history in a more analytical way than ever before
Writing essays, reading primary sources, making inferences about history from literature

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the Professor was great, the small size (5 students) facilitated good discussion, the Professors short lectures at the beginning put the readings into context, the short weekly papers helped me synthesize my thoughts, very fun class atmosphere. 
Weaknesses: maybe this course would be better as a 2 hour seminar? The work felt very front loaded (most writing, reading, and discussion for the first meeting, the second weekly meetings didnt feel as productive as the first weekly meetings). But other than this minor point, no real weaknesses.

Strengths: enjoyable readings (good length, allowing for in-depth analysis), really helps you become a better writer! The class format was also helpful; the weekly reading reflections/responses were great for learning to analyze literary sources.
Weaknesses: the comments of the professor can be insensitive at times.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom always inhibits discussion, but I think the Professor and the class did their best in light of the circumstances.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes-I dont know if/when this course will be offered again, but if youre interested in medieval studies/history/literature, this course is really fun. The workload is also interesting and manageable, so this class might also be good if youre thinking about studying history/medieval history but arent sure.
Yes, given that they are interested in medieval history.
